reviews.review_msg: Great professor, tough class. Semiconductor physics is tough but he makes it manageable. 2nd midterm was fair, 1st was tough and the final was a curveball but he likely scaled as class average was a B- so overall he is fair. To do well on the tests review and understand homework and tutorial questions. Know how to use the associated formulas.
She's a great prof. She has office hours each week and accommodates office hours before each exam for last minute questions. Replies to emails pretty quickly too
She is nice and fun. Hand writing is not clear sometimes. and she won't post notes online. super nice in her office hours. If you go she will help you until you get the concepts. very patient !

Has a good understanding of the subject and is able to deliver that knowledge in an interesting and engaging way. He is a good professor for any class that he teaches, and if you compare him to the rest of the faculty he's a saint. Exams are rough but the subject matter is rough as well since most people aren't cut out to be chemical physicists.

Horrible, dates on exams change so your personal commitments don't matter, the weight of exams he also changes whenever he wants. The worst prof at SFU does not respect student-prof agreement at the start (course outline). The exams are poorly made, making the averages very low, just a bad experience overall.

Lecture notes are little vague, but doubling-down on the textbook will suffice. Is very experienced and knows what works and what doesn't. Tests are tricky but never feel impossible. Has a very generous curving policy and provides a "lifeline" second chance to not fail the course. Put time into the course and you will probably learn something.

ENSC470. Labs were clear and a great part to learning concepts while not being too time-consuming. Lectures were easy to follow. Shawn is also a very understanding professor with fair policies. MT was also simple, just need a lot of practice. Final difficulty depends on the MT - if it was easy, final would be more difficult. Fair course overall..

Shawn's teaching was really great in both ENSC 324 and ENSC 470 last summer. He always answers anything related to course material in detail and his words were easy to understand. I can see the potential from Shawn that he can teach other ENSC courses significantly better than other profs other than ENSC 324 and ENSC 470.
This class was very challenging for me but Shawn was a great lecturer and very fair with how he awarded marks. He is a super nice guy I would love to have him in other classes

Shawn is a great prof and I particularly appreciate his slides. I find that many professors do not create slides that accurately represent the material that is tested or on homework. His grading criteria and methods were fair and I believe that if you will get a mark proportional to the effort you put into this course which is how it should be.
I wasn't too interested in the material but he made accomodations for students when possible and gave resources for exams, overall good

I started liking the topics (semiconductors) when I took this class with him. I used to have a hard time understanding semiconductors before with other profs, but prof Shawn is very good at explaining and cares about explaining well. He is very organized and reasonable with his lecture structure, also he is very
kind person always willing to help.

Shawn teaches a difficult class in ENSC 324, but makes it less painful by assigning a reasonable amount of homework, and giving access to plenty of practice problems to study before exams. He is also very easy to contact, and thoughtful enough to give homework extensions. Lectures are a little dry, but overall a great professor.
